R Packages and Users Observatory 1.0.1
  • Get started
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Get Started

Source: vignettes/articles/github-observatory.Rmd
github-observatory.Rmd

Setup

  1. Install github.observatory by using:
install.packages("remotes")
remotes::install_github("harell/github.observatory")
  1. Set AWS credentials in order to get access to the curated data
Sys.setenv(
    AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID = "<your-access-key-id>",
    AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY= "<your-secret>",
    AWS_REGION = "ap-southeast-2"
)
  1. github.observatory gives easy access to the project database through a Repository object named Ecosystem. To access the database, instantiate a Ecosystem object.
ecos <- Ecosystem$new()
  1. Instantiate a Recommendation Agent. See Agent Functions for details.
agent <- Agent$new(ecos)

Terminology

Entities

  • Package: An R package that is available on CRAN. For example, dplyr.
  • Repo: A Github reposetory that corresponds to a Package. For example, tidyverse/dplyr.
  • User: A Github user. There are two ways to identify a User:
    • user_login this is a mutable name of the Github account chosen by the User. It is apparent in the Github URL. For example, https://github.com/harell corresponds to user_login = harell; and
    • user_id this is an immutable number assign by Github when the User creates an account. user_id is not readily available and has to be deduced from an API call. For example, user_id = 7226303, corresponds to user_login = harell , and the respective API call is https://api.github.com/user/7226303.

Tip: Among the two options to identify a User, user_id is preferable as it stays the same throughout the life of GitHub. See the Mapping Entities section for how to locate user_id with user_login.

Roles

  • Stargazer: A User that give a ★ (star) to a Repo.

Ecosystem Overview

The Ecosystem gives access to SPECTATOR, FOLLOWING, DEPENDENCY, PACKAGE, REPO and USER tables.

Tip: See the tables content at the Appendix

Mapping Entities

user_id to user_login

Finding a user_id with user_login

user_login <- "harell"
(
    user_id <- ecos$read_USER()
    |> dplyr::filter(login %in% user_login)
    |> dplyr::pull(id)
)
#> [1] 7226303

package (CRAN package name) to repo_id 

cran_package <- "dplyr"
(
    repo_id <- ecos$read_REPO()
    |> dplyr::filter(package %in% cran_package)
    |> dplyr::pull(id)
)
#> [1] 6427813

Agent Functions

The Recommendation Agent has five functions:

  1. recommend_repos_to_user Given a user_id suggests n repos the user might like;
  2. recommend_users_to_user Given a user_id suggests n users the user might like;
  3. query_repos_graph Given a repo_id and a method, find all linked packages in degrees degrees of separation;
  4. query_users_graph Given a user_id and a method, find all linked users in degrees degrees of separation; and
  5. query_package_stats Given a CRAN package name, and a particular statistic (a function of the data sample), return the value of the requested attribute.

Recommend Repos to a User

  1. Recommend 5 Repos to a user (see Agent help file for supported methods)
suggested_repos <- agent$recommend_repos_to_user(user_id, n = 5, method = "random")
print(suggested_repos)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 2
#>    rank   repo_id
#>   <int>     <int>
#> 1     1 302287423
#> 2     2 117861877
#> 3     3  28145342
#> 4     4 308463829
#> 5     5 255877129
  1. Add details to the recommended Repos
(
    suggested_repos
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_REPO(), by = c("repo_id" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 16
#>    rank  repo_id package full_name owner_type owner_id html_url stargazers_count
#>   <int>    <dbl> <chr>   <chr>     <chr>         <dbl> <chr>               <dbl>
#> 1     1   3.02e8 mcmcen… bisaloo/… User       10783929 https:/…                1
#> 2     2   1.18e8 lmerTe… runehaub… User        5217453 https:/…               36
#> 3     3   2.81e7 igraph… igraph/i… Organizat…  3735184 https:/…               45
#> 4     4   3.08e8 censo2… ropensci… Organizat…  1200269 https:/…               19
#> 5     5   2.56e8 mlr3be… mlr-org/… Organizat… 12941794 https:/…                8
#> # … with 8 more variables: watchers_count <dbl>, forks_count <dbl>,
#> #   language <chr>, homepage <chr>, created_at <date>, updated_at <date>,
#> #   queried_at <date>, processed_at <date>

Recommend Users to a User

  1. Recommend 5 Users to a user (see Agent help file for supported methods)
suggested_users <- agent$recommend_users_to_user(user_id, n = 5, method = "random")
print(suggested_users)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 2
#>    rank  user_id
#>   <int>    <int>
#> 1     1 26463953
#> 2     2 22375427
#> 3     3 46222195
#> 4     4  8527082
#> 5     5 13743685
  1. Add details to the recommended Users
(
    suggested_users
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_USER(), by = c("user_id" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 5 × 18
#>    rank user_id login avatar_url html_url name  public_repos followers following
#>   <int>   <dbl> <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1     1  2.65e7 maxi… https://a… https:/… Maxi…           15        11        30
#> 2     2  2.24e7 ediab https://a… https:/… Elias            1         5        24
#> 3     3  4.62e7 yang… https://a… https:/… Yi Y…           57         0        15
#> 4     4  8.53e6 psyg… https://a… https:/… Mh M…           75         4        36
#> 5     5  1.37e7 cici… https://a… https:/… NA               6         2        49
#> # … with 9 more variables: r_followers <dbl>, r_following <dbl>,
#> #   r_contributor_count <dbl>, r_stargazer_count <dbl>, r_watcher_count <dbl>,
#> #   created_at <date>, updated_at <date>, queried_at <date>,
#> #   processed_at <date>

Query Repos Graph

To query the repo graph, you need to supply three input arguments:

  • repo_id: See Mapping Entities for how to map a package name to repo_id);
  • degree: How many neighbourhood to retrieve?
  • method: Either depends or reverse depends
    • depends returns the package dependencies (as appears in its DESCRIPTION file);
    • reverse depends returns packages that are dependent on repo_id.

Query package dependencies

  1. Find the dependencies of a package
repo_dep <- agent$query_repos_graph(repo_id, degrees = 1, method = "depends")
print(repo_dep)
#> # A tibble: 11 × 3
#>    degree    from        to
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1      0 6427813   6427813
#>  2      1 6427813 137095400
#>  3      1 6427813  77250656
#>  4      1 6427813 163315535
#>  5      1 6427813  15564525
#>  6      1 6427813  91374446
#>  7      1 6427813  19521307
#>  8      1 6427813  73098312
#>  9      1 6427813  45148983
#> 10      1 6427813  92205415
#> 11      1 6427813  67548397
  1. Add details to the Package dependencies
(
    repo_dep
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_REPO(), by = c("to" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 11 × 17
#>    degree    from        to package    full_name    owner_type owner_id html_url
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>     <dbl> <chr>      <chr>        <chr>         <dbl> <chr>   
#>  1      0 6427813   6427813 dplyr      tidyverse/d… Organizat… 22032646 https:/…
#>  2      1 6427813 137095400 generics   r-lib/gener… Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#>  3      1 6427813  77250656 glue       tidyverse/g… Organizat… 22032646 https:/…
#>  4      1 6427813 163315535 lifecycle  r-lib/lifec… Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#>  5      1 6427813  15564525 magrittr   tidyverse/m… Organizat… 22032646 https:/…
#>  6      1 6427813  91374446 pillar     r-lib/pillar Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#>  7      1 6427813  19521307 R6         r-lib/r6     Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#>  8      1 6427813  73098312 rlang      r-lib/rlang  Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#>  9      1 6427813  45148983 tibble     tidyverse/t… Organizat… 22032646 https:/…
#> 10      1 6427813  92205415 tidyselect r-lib/tidys… Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#> 11      1 6427813  67548397 vctrs      r-lib/vctrs  Organizat… 22618716 https:/…
#> # … with 9 more variables: stargazers_count <dbl>, watchers_count <dbl>,
#> #   forks_count <dbl>, language <chr>, homepage <chr>, created_at <date>,
#> #   updated_at <date>, queried_at <date>, processed_at <date>

Query package reverse dependencies

  1. Find the reverse dependencies of a package
repo_rev_dep <- agent$query_repos_graph(repo_id, degrees = 1, method = "reverse")
print(repo_rev_dep)
#> # A tibble: 2,592 × 3
#>    degree      from      to
#>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1      0   6427813 6427813
#>  2      1 221466628 6427813
#>  3      1  78038172 6427813
#>  4      1 340095903 6427813
#>  5      1 201294705 6427813
#>  6      1  80061030 6427813
#>  7      1 447452022 6427813
#>  8      1  39196192 6427813
#>  9      1 334079562 6427813
#> 10      1 244196790 6427813
#> # … with 2,582 more rows
  1. Add details to the Package dependencies
(
    repo_rev_dep
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_REPO(), by = c("from" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 2,592 × 17
#>    degree      from      to package       full_name owner_type owner_id html_url
#>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl> <chr>         <chr>     <chr>         <dbl> <chr>   
#>  1      0   6427813 6427813 dplyr         tidyvers… Organizat… 22032646 https:/…
#>  2      1 221466628 6427813 AATtools      spiritsp… User       35294148 https:/…
#>  3      1  78038172 6427813 abjutils      cran/abj… Organizat…  6899542 https:/…
#>  4      1 340095903 6427813 academictwit… cjbarrie… User       29574597 https:/…
#>  5      1 201294705 6427813 accept        cran/acc… Organizat…  6899542 https:/…
#>  6      1  80061030 6427813 accucor       xiaoyang… User       14297111 https:/…
#>  7      1 447452022 6427813 ACDC          cran/acdc Organizat…  6899542 https:/…
#>  8      1  39196192 6427813 ACDm          cran/acdm Organizat…  6899542 https:/…

#> #   created_at <date>, updated_at <date>, queried_at <date>,
#> #   processed_at <date>

Query Users Graph

To query the repo graph, you need to supply three input arguments:

  • repo_id: See Mapping Entities for how to map a package name to repo_id);
  • degree: How many neighbourhood to retrieve?
  • method: Either followers or following
    • followers What users are following user_id?; or
    • following What users is user_id following?

Query user followers

  1. Find who is following user_id 
user_followers <- agent$query_users_graph(user_id, degrees = 1, method = "followers")
print(user_followers)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 3
#>   degree     from      to
#>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl>
#> 1      0  7226303 7226303
#> 2      1 52979198 7226303
#> 3      1 31113760 7226303
#> 4      1 10200210 7226303
#> 5      1  3811321 7226303
#> 6      1  6518676 7226303
  1. Add details to user_id followers
(
    user_followers
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_USER(), by = c("from" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 6 × 19
#>   degree     from      to login avatar_url html_url name  public_repos followers
#>    <dbl>    <dbl>   <dbl> <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl>
#> 1      0  7226303 7226303 hare… https://a… https:/… NA              13         6
#> 2      1 52979198 7226303 ange… https://a… https:/… Ange…            6         9
#> 3      1 31113760 7226303 rfdo… https://a… https:/… Rodr…            9        37
#> 4      1 10200210 7226303 asds… https://a… https:/… NA              22         5
#> 5      1  3811321 7226303 mask… https://a… https:/… Am             344        82
#> 6      1  6518676 7226303 bcga… https://a… https:/… Brya…           19        41
#> # … with 10 more variables: following <dbl>, r_followers <dbl>,
#> #   r_following <dbl>, r_contributor_count <dbl>, r_stargazer_count <dbl>,
#> #   r_watcher_count <dbl>, created_at <date>, updated_at <date>,
#> #   queried_at <date>, processed_at <date>

Query user following

  1. Find who is user_id following
user_following <- agent$query_users_graph(user_id, degrees = 1, method = "following")
print(user_following)
#> # A tibble: 56 × 3
#>    degree    from      to
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl>
#>  1      0 7226303 7226303
#>  2      1 7226303    4196
#>  3      1 7226303   86978
#>  4      1 7226303   93231
#>  5      1 7226303  104391
#>  6      1 7226303  129551
#>  7      1 7226303  205275
#>  8      1 7226303  216319
#>  9      1 7226303  227097
#> 10      1 7226303  470418
#> # … with 46 more rows
  1. Add details to those who user_id is following
(
    user_following
    |> dplyr::left_join(ecos$read_USER(), by = c("to" = "id"))
)
#> # A tibble: 56 × 19
#>    degree    from      to login avatar_url html_url name  public_repos followers
#>     <dbl>   <dbl>   <dbl> <chr> <chr>      <chr>    <chr>        <dbl>     <dbl>
#>  1      0 7226303 7226303 hare… https://a… https:/… NA              13         6

#> #   r_stargazer_count <dbl>, r_watcher_count <dbl>, created_at <date>,
#> #   updated_at <date>, queried_at <date>, processed_at <date>

Query Package Stats

Monthly Downloads

  1. Find how many times dplyr was downloaded every month
package_downloads <- agent$query_package_stats("dplyr", statistic = "monthly downloads")
package_downloads |> tail(n = 12) |> print()
#> # A tibble: 12 × 3
#>    date       package downloads
#>    <date>     <chr>       <dbl>
#>  1 2021-07-01 dplyr     1453335
#>  2 2021-08-01 dplyr     1483396
#>  3 2021-09-01 dplyr     1630109
#>  4 2021-10-01 dplyr     1821037
#>  5 2021-11-01 dplyr     1680463
#>  6 2021-12-01 dplyr     1438504
#>  7 2022-01-01 dplyr     1411385
#>  8 2022-02-01 dplyr     1552862
#>  9 2022-03-01 dplyr     1764950
#> 10 2022-04-01 dplyr     1791634
#> 11 2022-05-01 dplyr     2132210
#> 12 2022-06-01 dplyr     1855881
  1. Plot the monthly downloads
plot(
    package_downloads$date, package_downloads$downloads, 
    main = "Monthly downloads of `dplyr` from RStudio CRAN mirror",
    type = "b", xlab = "Date", ylab = "Monthly Downloads"
)
